questions.title: BYCATCH
questions.description: Bycatch are fish or sea creatures that are caught unintentionally with the species that a fisher is targeting, including young or undersized fish. Bycatch disrupt the food chain by taking fish that other species rely on for food.

imageMetadata.altText: Funny sea turtle

questions.title: What happens to bycatch?
questions.description: It is difficult to solve the problem of bycatch entirely, because different marine creatures swim together under the sea. Fishers will often discard the fish that they did not want to catch, cannot sell and are not allowed to keep.

imageMetadata.altText: Freshly caught mackerel in a fishing net

questions.title: Reducing bycatch
questions.description: Bycatch can be reduced by using science and technology to improve our fishing methods and gear types such as Gillnets and Turtle Exclusion Devices.

questions.title: The MSC Fisheries Standard
questions.description: Fisheries that hold the MSC blue fish tick label must demonstrate that they have very few instances of bycatch, and that they have implemented measures to improve fishing methods and gear, and reduce bycatch.

questions.question: Why is bycatch a problem?

choices.answer: Bycatch can disrupt the marine food web
Bycatch can be accidentally caught, injured or killed
Bycatch is a risk for threatened or endangered marine species

imageMetadata.altText: Fish boat vessel fishing in a rough sea

questions.question: Bycatch are fish or sea creatures that...

choices.answer: Are caught unintentionally with the species that a fisher is targeting
Are the species that a fisher is targeting
Are caught when they are undersized

imageMetadata.altText: Fishing Trawler

questions.question: Fishers are allowed to keep bycatch

imageMetadata.altText: USA, Maine, St. George, Fisherman putting rubber band on lobster

questions.question: It is easy to catch fish without getting any bycatch

imageMetadata.altText: Fishing net isolated. Background or design element.

questions.question: How can we reduce bycatch?

choices.answer: Using different types of fishing gear
Using science to learn more about the species we are catching
Only fishing at certain times of day or night

imageMetadata.altText: Marine biologist taking plankton samples from net on research ship

questions.title: GHOST FISHING
questions.description: Ghost nets are fishing nets that have been lost or thrown away at sea. Ghost nets continue to catch fish beneath the ocean. They also get tangled with animals such as turtles, birds, sharks and seals.

imageMetadata.altText: Fisherman

questions.question: What are ghost nets?

choices.answer: Nets that have been lost or thrown away at sea

imageMetadata.altText: Environmental Issue ocean pollution Ghost Net fishing industry

questions.title: How bad is the problem of ghost fishing?
questions.description: It has been said that almost half (46%) of the plastic in the ‘Great Pacific Garbage Patch’ is from fishing nets. It is also estimated that at least 640,000 tonnes of fishing gear is lost each year - the equivalent of 90,000 double decker buses!

imageMetadata.altText: concept of global pollution. The sea full of garbage on the background of nature. Save the planet.

questions.question: Ghost nets may be eaten by fish and other marine creatures

imageMetadata.altText: Ghost net

questions.question: Ghost nets continue to catch marine life

imageMetadata.altText: sea lion underwater looking at you

questions.question: How much of the plastic in the Great Pacific Garbage patch is estimated to come from ghost fishing gear?

imageMetadata.altText: Close up of a pile of tangled up commercial fishing nets.

questions.question: The Marine Stewardship Council (MSC) considers the effect of ghost gear in its Fisheries Standard

questions.title: ENDANGERED & DELICATE MARINE HABITATS
questions.description: Delicate marine habitats are places in the ocean that are breeding grounds for animals, or where endangered or slow growing creatures (like sea sponges) grow.

imageMetadata.altText: coral reef

questions.title: Marine Habitats and Overfishing
questions.description: Fishing gear can affect delicate marine habitats. For example, large trawl nets can damage the sea floor, and fishing traps may cause damage to coral reefs. Overfishing herbivorous algae-eating fish can also cause toxic algae blooms to grow.

imageMetadata.altText: fishing

questions.title: Protecting Delicate Habitats
questions.description: To receive the MSC blue fish tick, fisheries must show that they do little damage to marine habitats and do not use destructive fishing methods like explosives. In Australia there are also special zones of the ocean where fishing is not permitted.

questions.question: Which fishing gear causes damage to endangered marine habitats?

choices.answer: If not used properly, any fishing gear can cause damage to marine habitats

imageMetadata.altText: Italy, Puglia, TA, Ginosa, Marina di Ginosa, Italian Fishing Rod

questions.question: It is better for marine habitats to only catch herbivorous fish

imageMetadata.altText: Kelp Forest

questions.question: Protecting endangered habitats is considered under the MSC Fisheries Standard
The use of explosives is permitted under the MSC Fisheries Standard, if managed properly.

imageMetadata.altText: Full Frame Shot Of Water Splashing During Rainfall

questions.question: In Australia there are special marine protected zones where fishing is not permitted. The largest of these is the...

imageMetadata.altText: Aerial of Great Barrier Reef at Whitsunday Island

questions.title: SHARK FINNING
questions.description: Shark finning is the removal of fins from a shark and discarding the rest of the shark (often still living) to the sea. Sharks are caught for use in shark fin soup, considered a symbol of prosperity in Chinese tradition. One bowl can cost up to $100.

imageMetadata.altText: Shark fin above ocean water

questions.title: How healthy are shark populations?
questions.description: More than 30% of all known shark and ray species are in danger of extinction. More than half of some groups of sharks have disappeared because of shark fishing, and it can take a long time for populations to recover.

imageMetadata.altText: School of sharks circling from above

questions.title: Why are sharks important?
questions.description: Sharks play an important role in the ecosystem. As apex predators, they maintain the species below them and help to balance species diversity.

imageMetadata.altText: Hole through the baitball

questions.question: There are more than _____ species of shark and rays in the ocean today

imageMetadata.altText: stingray

questions.question: Shark finning is good for the marine food chain, and protects smaller species.

imageMetadata.altText: Danger area

questions.question: More than ___% of shark and ray species are in danger of extinction

imageMetadata.altText: Underwater Scene - Tropical Seabed With Reef And Sunshine.

questions.question: Shark finning is sometimes allowed in the MSC Fisheries Standard, depending on where the fishery is located.

questions.title: OVERFISHING
questions.description: Overfishing is when a certain species of fish, usually one people like to eat, is fished too much so that fish are unable to reproduce their numbers to a healthy level and begin to decline. Today, almost one third of global fish stocks are overfished

imageMetadata.altText: fishing purse seine

questions.title: Why is there a problem?
questions.description: There are strict national and global rules in place to prevent overfishing, however illegal fishing remains a big problem. Destructive fishing practices can also destroy the underwater environment.

imageMetadata.altText: No fishing sign

questions.title: Should we stop eating fish altogether?
questions.description: Billions of people all over the world rely on fish as an essential source of protein in their diets, or rely on fishing for their livelihood. As such, wanting the world to stop eating fish is not a practical solution to overfishing.

imageMetadata.altText: Close-up view of grilled sardine fishes served in oil with baked potatoes, Portugal

questions.title: What are the Marine Stewardship Council doing?
questions.description: The MSC was created to address the problem of overfishing. The MSC works with fishers around the world to fish sustainably. Fisheries that demonstrate sustainable fishing practices by meeting the MSC Fisheries Standard can use the MSC blue fish tick.

questions.question: Today almost one third of global fish stocks are overfished

imageMetadata.altText: Herring's catch

questions.question: Overfishing can include

choices.answer: Taking too many fish so that a species cannot reproduce

imageMetadata.altText: Scenic View of Seagulls above Sea Against Sky During Sunset, Thailand

questions.question: The reason that overfishing happens is that there are no rules in place to prevent it

imageMetadata.altText: White black coast guard vessel at sea.

questions.question: Illegal fishing can refer to...

choices.answer: Catching species you aren't allowed to catch
Fishing in areas where you are not supposed to fish
Not reporting your catch to the fishing authorities

imageMetadata.altText: Even cat has a choice
